data.title: not for steak
data.text: tried their dry aged steak. Did not seem similar or as good as other dry aged steak I've had. In fact, seemed worse than the steak and eggs you get at Denny's. Ambience is decent though. I'd go for appetizers and a few drinks again though

data.title: Under delivers and over priced.
data.text:
Located in the ground floor of what appears to be an office building, as you approach the entrance, your first sight is of a meat locker where they are dry aging beef. This was a good sign.

Upon arrival for my reservation shortly after the restaurant opened, we taken to our table right away with no wait. We were seated in the lower dining area, at a 6 top, in a dark corner of the room vs upstairs in the brighter main room. There were just two of us. There was a lack of attention to detail - the online dinner menu does not show the grass fed options, we were not offered the pre-fixe menu, the menu at the entrance to the building did not match what we were given and our server left the additional 4 place settings at the table.

On a non-holiday, Friday night, we ordered the wedge salad with romaine vs iceberg lettuce, beef spring rolls and grass fed beef Porterhouse for two (@ $74). Shortly after that we were told that the grass fed porterhouse was not available, but we could get the regular porterhouse or grass fed t-bone. When further questioned, our server proceeded to tell us that the t-bone is the same as the porterhouse, only a thinner cut. (Unless you're in the know, that "thinner cut" is of the tender loin side of the steak.) As we wanted to try their grass fed beef, we went with the T-Bone. Not realising until the bill came, that were charged for two single serve steaks (@ $49 each), a price change that our server did not explain at the time we made the order change. How can you be out of a signature item and not let the servers know at the start of service?

While the meat was cooked well and full of beef flavour, it should have been called a strip steak - the loin on my piece was a small triangle measuring in width .25" to 1" and about 2" long, hardly worth putting on the bone. As I had mentioned before attention to detail was lacking, because also on my plate was a 2" long burnt parsnip, served burnt side up. That burnt parsnip should have never made it out of the kitchen - both expediter and server should have caught it.

Upon leaving, we saw why we might not have been seated in the main dining room - it was filled with a college sports team. Perhaps this might have also explained not offering a prix fix menu? Nothing was communicated at check-in or throughout the dining experience.

It was not worth the high price, average service, and lack of attention to details, poor communication and managing expectations that evening. I would not go back, even if someone else was paying.

data.title: Overpriced for what you receive
data.text:
We had dinner at Porterhouse this past Friday evening, and I must say I was unimpressed. For a steakhouse that charges as much as they do, I expected quite a bit more.

When we arrived we were greeted at the host stand and taken to our table right away. Since this was an early dinner (5:30) this was as expected, but I didn't expect the two of us to be seated at a 6-top table in a dark corner of the downstairs dining room. We had a reservation that had been booked several weeks earlier, it isn't like we showed up unannounced.

Having looked at their menu on the web site when we made the reservation, I was looking forward to trying their prix fixe menu. However, there was no sign of this, just a single page menu that is similar to the daily menu they have on-line. The menu you receive in the restaurant is however slightly different from both the one on-line and the one posted outside the restaurant, apparently no one has the time to walk out to the the front and change it.

Since this is a steakhouse, we decided to order their grass fed porterhouse for two (not on the on-line menu) along with an appetizer and salad for each of us. They were good enough to customize the salad but the server completely forgot about the appetizer. He also came back shortly after we ordered to tell us that the grass fed porterhouse was not available but we could get the regular porterhouse or the grass fed t-bone. When questioned he proceeded to tell us that the t-bone was the same as the porterhouse only a thinner cut, which is not correct. That's like saying that a strip steak is the same as a t-bone -- they may come from the same primal but they are not the same. As many have said, all porterhouses are t-bones, but not all t-bones are porterhouses.

What restaurant is out of their signature item at 6pm on a Friday night?

As we wanted to try their grass-fed beef, we went with the t-bone, not realizing that this was a more expensive cut since it was two single-serving steaks as compared to the the porterhouse which is priced for 2 people. This of course was not explained to us by the server.

The steaks themselves were very good. They are well aged to develop flavor and were cooked perfectly. They were not cut very evenly though, as my partner's steak was about 50% thicker than mine and was cut from further up the primal. Mine appeared to be from the every end of what can be considered a t-bone.

Overall, I feel the dinner was not worth the high price we paid. The service was below average, I felt that we were dining in an overflow room, and the price was somewhat outrageous for what we had to eat. I doubt we will ever go back, I would much rather go to Alexander's in Cupertino where I can have a much wider selection, better service, and pay roughly the same price in a nicer atmosphere.

data.title: Very good steakhouse
data.text: Excellent cuts of dry, aged beef that you can see as you walk in.  Great place on peninsula to get high quality steak.

data.title: First time, Nice time
data.text: We had a group of ten for a party and it was our first time there. A bit pricey but food and service were both great. Several different meals and everyone thought they were delicious. Will go back. Would give it 4.5 of 5 if available.

data.title: First visit. Nice surprise.
data.text: A nice surprise. Not very busy as a very heavy rain. Daughters took me for birthday. Staff & owners very nice people. Food was very good. A little pricey but was worth it..

data.title: Tasty pricey friendly
data.text:
Tasty cowboy ribeye on the bone $42, but it really didn't look like an 18 ounce steak. Cooked right, medium rare. Waiter over-friendly/presumptuous (thought he was a comedy club Henny Youngman, but some of the insult comedy was funny and he was a nice man in his way. Risky with business customers at a steakhouse) 

In the end it was a good meal. The brussels sprouts with bacon side was way too oily and too few brussels sprouts. Accompanying stuffed baked potato was a highlight, as were the onions on the steak. Friends had prime rib - cooked right but small for the price.

Really delish Sonoma Cabernet by the glass.

data.title: Great steak house - and local!
data.text: Great traditional steakhouse that I had never heard of before finding it here. And I live a half mile away! Does not have a storefront on the street, so you have to know it is there. Specialty is dry-aged steaks, which were terrific. Also has excellent service. Loved the truffle oil mac and cheese. Also tried their tagliatelle ragu, which was quite good. A little too much dressing on the wedge salad. I would go again, though it would be mostly for special occasions, since it is a bit pricey (although on par for a true steakhouse).

data.title: Looking for a good steak and found one!
data.text: I am working in the area south of San Francisco and some colleagues and I wanted to find a good steak to eat.   We were going to travel 45 minutes south but was pointed in the direction of the Porterhouse.  When you walk in from 3rd Ave it is in the back of a building and you begin to wonder if you are in the right place but when you find it your experience begins.   We ate there on a Tuesday evening and the place was full.  I had the Filet Mignon and I would have to say that it was one of the best that I have had.   My other colleagues had great praise for the steaks that they had ordered.   It is not the cheapest restaurant in the area but we were looking for a good steak and we found one.   I will plan on eating there again when I am in town.

data.title: COWBOY STEAK ON POINT!!
data.text: Everything was delicious! Dined here with a friend on April 6th.  We both ordered the Cowboy Steak which came with a tasty Baked Potato and Vegetables. The Cowboy Steak is huge.  I also ordered a Bleu Cheese Salad, a Cosmopolitan from the bar and at the end of dinner...Bread Pudding to go.  Porterhouse is expensive but definitely worth it.  The ambiance is very nice and I need to mention the bread they serve before your main course...had a few baskets because it was so soft and good.

data.title: WOW Great Steak & Wine List
data.text:
Extremely  tasty steaks . Nice choice of aged steaks. Great Wine List

Service was top notch. IN downtown San Mateo... charming location

data.title: Everything was great except for the steak
data.text: My party of 9 ate at the Porterhouse Restaurant on Christmas Eve. The atmosphere, staff, and service were all great. However, my $42 rib eye steak was pretty much flavorless. My wife also had the rib eye and felt the same. We were very disappointed in the steak, especially since it was the cut recommended by our server. I've had much better steaks at less than half the price.

data.title: Beautiful and Delicious
data.text: Hosted a birthday party for ten people. Our square table(perfect for a large group) was set in a lovely room surrounded with glass and lots of candles. The food was delicious and the service was very good, other than the one latecomer received his food ten minutes before the rest of us.  Seemed odd. Overall, they did a great job. (Also, an elegant restaurant with a pretty tacky old hallway entrance)

data.title: Dry aged steaks
data.text: Really nice restaurant and bar.  They serve great dry aged steaks prepared to perfection.  If you have never tried a dry aged steak this would be a good place to start. The french onion soup was delicious.  We were in with a group and they provided a super bruchetta (sp) , good chicken wings and a very nice cheese plate for appetizers.  Great Creme Brulee and chocolate mousse.  Super service.  The bar is very congenial and has a huge selection of libations-generously poured.

data.title: Great surprise and Beef, Beef and Beef
data.text: The meat choices are excellent, if the have the dry aged beef--have it.  The steaks, rib eye and porterhouse are excellent our group had them all.  Large portions and good service.  The wine list is good, with variety and strength in the reds.  The atmosphere is like an old steak house, a little dark, dark wood and low lighting.  The deserts are worth sharing.  Parking can be a little difficult, so allow a few extra minutes to park.

data.title: It was good
data.text:
Wife, sister, and I enjoyed a dinner at Porterhouse in June 2015. I engaged the online reservation option found here on TA and it worked flawlessly. 

I was a little concerned about finding the place after having read some of the reviews but it was in no way problematic. You can park in the adjacent public garage and have quick access to the restaurant. I parked on the roof and saw the sign for the place by one of the entries. It is near the terminus of the ramp that leads to the roof. Parking was free after 6 pm. Once you get onto the ground floor of the building, it's not at all difficult to find the place. There is adequate directional signage. 

Porterhouse is not decked out in contemporary trappings. It reminded me of the classic '60's or '70's steakhouse. But as long as it delivered on the chow, it mattered not to me what the place looked like. 

And it pretty much delivered. 

Wife and I each ordered the 12-oz. cut of prime rib and my sister, suffering from an upset stomach, ordered the risotto. 

For appetizers, I had the hearts of romaine, and wife had escargots. The salad was quite tasty with its authentic Caesar dressing. The escargot was great, deliciousness which was enhanced by the rich garlic and oil sauce. 

The prime rib was perfectly cooked but given I was really hungry, I wished it would have been a 16-oz. cut. The presentation was elegant. The meat was flanked by a tubular twice-baked potato, broccoli, and au jus. The broccoli was just right. That's not easy to do (at least that's what I think).  Sister perked up a little after having finished her risotto. Not only did she feel better, she decided to order dessert. 

In her case, it was the creme brûlée.  Wife and I split the bananas foster. What a production that was!  They cook it right abeam the table. When the liqueur was administered, there was a great flash of fire that shot up almost to the ceiling fan. Theatrics aside, the result was a great dessert. The reviewer who said she wanted to lick the dish - I get it. 

Dinner here is almost obligatory for visitors to San Mateo. Don't be put off by location. Go and enjoy.

data.title: Several Issues Marred the Experience
data.text:
While staying at a hotel near SFO, my wife, adult son, and I decided to forego the Marriott Hotel restaurant and instead try something a bit more upscale. This brought us to the Porterhouse in San Mateo. The entrance to the actual restaurant is at the end of a corridor. The ambiance of the dining area is sort of Capital Grille-ish...dark wood and leather, etc., although not as elegant.  The hostess was very friendly and helpful – in fact the nicest person working there. My son really enjoyed his prime rib; my filet came out medium instead of medium rare. My wife had issues with the soup--too spicy and the waiter called over a "suit" (there were more male suits running about then servers) who accused my wife of putting pepper in the soup (she has never put pepper on anything at any restaurant). Her entree was a spring salad that was short on everything - not much substance.  The molten chocolate cake was very good but took forever to get.  When we questioned the time one of the pompous “suits” said that it took a half hour – an item they failed to mention when we ordered it. 

Two non-food items: first, the public parking garages, though free, puts you far from the restaurant.  It was confusing to know which one to park in; secondly, the restrooms are not in the restaurant, but in that corridor noted above. Supposedly, there is a code to punch in, but that night they were wide open--very unsafe due to easy street access.

All in all, for the price paid and the other issues, it was not a worthwhile dining experience.  Nest time we are in San Mateo, we will try another restaurant.

data.title: very good steakhouse!
data.text: Our steaks were excellent, they had amazing desserts, the was a great wine selection and the service was very good.

data.title: Oh yes, that's steak!
data.text:
What a great restaurant.  It is in a bit of an odd location hidden down a corridor.  Also the toilets/restrooms are the other side of the corridor to the restaurant.  But that aside it's really good.

The choice of steaks was very impressive and our table of 6 had a mixture of the fayre available, 3 of us going for the cowboy.  

Starters from Oysters, Crab Cakes, spicy chicken wings, chilled prawns - all went down well.

The steak - perfect.  One of the best I have had and really enjoyable.  
Wine selection is incredible
Service was attentive but not invasive

Really good meal, I would certainl return

data.title: GREAT PLACE FOR BEEF
data.text:
Excellent steak I would have ordered the prime rib but it was to big even if we would have split the dish.  Everything was good, even the cocktails not every place knows how to make a French Martini!   Our waiter was very nice and helpful.
Be prepared to spend some money but it's worth it especially for a special occasion.
